awd_titl_txt: Using Dense Seismic Arrays to Determine Structure in the Los Angeles Basin
awd_abstract_narration:
With this study we plan to combine seismic data from oil-company surveys with the earthquake seismic data from the Southern California Seismic Network to determine the velocity in the top 1-3 km of the surface in the Los Angeles Basin. This information is important because it directly bears on the level of shaking that can be expected from earthquakes due to the variations soils and subsurface structures. It will be used along with actual measurements of ground shaking to determine maps of seismic hazard for the central part of the Los Angeles Basin. In addition, we will use the dense coverage provided by the oil-company surveys to determine the micro-earthquake activity in the basin. This is important for understanding the physical process that generates the earthquakes in Los Angeles.

The subsurface velocity structure will be determined by surface waves and refracted body waves. These waves will be extracted from the ambient noise field by cross-correlation of the oil-company and earthquake-monitoring data. The source that generates these waves is ocean microseisms, and hence is always present. The correlations will be done over many days and will use small-aperture sub-arrays to minimize the background noise. The result will be a map of the near-surface shear and compressional wave velocities for the central basin, where the ray coverage is the densest. The near-surface velocities will then be added to the reference model of the Los Angeles region (SCEC velocity model) to make a complete velocity model that can be used to simulated earthquake-generated wave in the basin.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this study is to provide a detailed map of the shear wave velocities in the top 1-2 km of the subsurface in the Los Angeles area. These velocities are the main controlling factor to the level of ground shaking due to earthquakes. The results show there are significant  lateral variations in these velocities and this is important because the low-velocity areas will likely  cause enhanced shaking. Knowing where these areas are, can mitigate the  damage and financial loss through zoning laws and guidance to first responders.  The velocities allow for a more accurate prediction of ground motions following an earthquake and for scenario earthquakes that can guide planning.

This project combined data from dense oil-company seismic surveys with academic earthquake networks in the Los Angeles area. These two datasets were cross-correlated to produce coverage from the coast to the central Los Angeles basin.  The results are presented in the accompanying figure, and show that the central basin has generally slow velocities (i.e. potentially high levels of shaking), and that there significant structural complexities associated with the Newport-Inglewood Fault that will produce strong lateral changes in the level of shaking.

To accomplish the goals of this study, we had to devise a method to process large numbers of correction pairs (several million) to determine the velocity. We did by developing a machine-learning procedure. In addition, we developed a method based on autocorrleations of the data to image the deeper subsurface, which helps in understanding the structure of the Los Angeles basin, and how it relates to the tectonics of the surrounding region.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/16/2021
Modified by: Robert W Clayton

Image
  • The inverted shear wave velocity model of the LA Basin. (a) Horizontal slides of the Vs model. The center map is the 1.5 km depth slice to illuminate the NW?SE trending high velocity zone.
    Jia and Clayton, 2021, J. Geophysical Res.
    Copyrighted
    Robert W Clayton
    Shear Wave Velocity in Los Angeles
